Scrapping the net-zero target creates a disconnect with the Paris Agreement, which requires global net-zero emissions by 2050. He also challenged the Coalition’s claim that new coal or nuclear plants are needed for grid reliability, pointing to existing idle backup capacity—such as open-cycle gas turbines and diesel generators—worth 10–20 gigawatts that are only used during rare supply gaps. Oregon Governor Tina Kotek issued an executive order on November 20, 2025, directing state agencies to accelerate clean energy project permitting and grid integration to meet the state’s climate goals. The order mandates collaboration among over a dozen land and natural resource agencies to develop policy proposals by September 2026 for legislative consideration in 2027, aiming to achieve a 50% reduction in greenhouse gas emissions by 2035 and 90% by 2050—targets established in a 2021 executive order by former Governor Kate Brown. The latest Oregon Energy Strategy prioritizes solar, wind, geothermal, wave energy, energy storage, and energy efficiency projects. Key actions include fast-tracking permitting for projects eligible for the Inflation Reduction Act’s clean energy tax credits, which expire December 31, 2027, and require completion by that date for up to a 50% credit. Kotek emphasized the need for faster grid upgrades and transmission corridor development, citing a ProPublica and Oregon Public Broadcasting investigation revealing that the Northwest lags due to decades of inaction by the federal Bonneville Power Administration (BPA), which has delayed grid modernization for nearly a century. Kotek called on BPA to fulfill its commitments and improve collaboration. The state plans to add 8 gigawatts of energy storage by 2045—about 50% more than current capacity—with nearly 7 gigawatts already in development, enough to power roughly 5.8 million homes. The Department of Environmental Quality and the Public Utility Commission will align Clean Fuels Program revenues with investments in transportation electrification, low-income communities, multifamily housing, and underserved EV charging areas. The Clean Fuels Program requires fossil fuel suppliers like Chevron and Exxon Mobil to reduce carbon intensity of fuels by at least 37% by 2035. Clean fuel producers can earn and sell carbon credits to offset emissions. Kotek also directed a 50% or greater reduction in fuel carbon intensity by 2040, encouraging biofuels and low-carbon alternatives. The Department of Administrative Services must transition state vehicle fleets to zero-emission models and report annually on combustion-engine vehicle purchases. The Department of Land Conservation and Development will propose changes to land use regulations to expand clean energy development and transmission corridors on public lands. Despite a projected $63 million budget deficit over the next 18 months, Kotek urged agencies to use existing resources and identify funding needs for the next budget cycle.
